Award.AwardTitle: Eastern Illinois Integrated Conference in Geometry, Dynamics, and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Eastern Illinois Integrated Conference in Geometry, Dynamics, and Topology, which will occur the weekend of April 15-17, 2016, at Eastern Illinois University. This conference is integrated in the sense that it draws participants at every stage of their mathematical careers, with particular focus on both early-career graduate students and undergraduates. A meeting of this type brings together researchers from the academically young to the well-established, yet offers a more narrow research focus than is typically found at undergraduate-inclusive conferences. This narrow focus serves to promote more meaningful contact in the context of mathematical research. The conference is intended to fuel young mathematicians' interest in research mathematics, promote inter- and intra-generational research ties, and demonstrate how undergraduates can be incorporated into research programs in these fields.

Three established speakers and three early-career speakers are invited by the organizing committee; these speakers are chosen both for their eminence in their respective fields and their ability to provide meaningful introductions to complex topics for audiences with a wide range of mathematical backgrounds. Invitations for submissions by graduate students and undergraduate students will be issued in mid-February. Submitted abstracts will be reviewed by subject-specific committees composed of faculty at Eastern Illinois University. Up to 6 graduate students and between 12 and 15 undergraduates will be invited to make presentations, either as talks or in poster sessions. In addition to the talks and poster sessions, the conference provides opportunities for less formal interaction, including social events on Friday and Saturday nights. Our increased focus on incorporating undergraduates into professional life includes panel discussions from funded graduate students and early-career mathematicians covering important but seldom-discussed aspects of attending graduate school and pursuing an academic career in mathematics.

More information will be available at the conference website: https://ux1.eiu.edu/~gdt/2016.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project initiated the expansion of a long-running annual conference at Eastern Illinois University in the areas of geometry, topology, and dynamical systems to a three-day event. Although the original award was for a single conference in 2016, funding was sufficient for a second conference in 2017. Through a second grant from the NSF, we have built upon the success of these initial conferences and look forward to continuing to annually host engaging and inclusive conferences in the years to come.

 

In addition to the extension of the conference from a single day to three, the project altered the focus of the event to involve mathematicians who are relatively new to research-- specifically, undergraduates and early-career graduate students-- while remaining a discipline-specific professional conference. This approach contributes to the integration of young mathematicians into the ongoing exchange of ideas in these fields and promotes undergraduate and early graduate research both among students and established faculty. The more narrow focus in terms of subject matter allows for a more in-depth discussion of student research, a more uniformly mathematically mature audience for presentations, and allows for the demonstration of how student research can be incorporated into the existing research programs of attending faculty. 


Special lectures were presented by three established mathematicians and three early-career scholars. Initially the organizers initially expected that the number of student presentations would need to be capped, careful budgeting allowed for all student participants, both undergraduate and graduate, to be funded according to their needs. While the 2016 conference was well-attended, the 2017 event expanded beyond the bounds of a regional conference, drawing attendees from both coasts. In addition to presentations, a panel discussion was hosted where attendees were encouraged to ask a panel of three participants-- a tenured professor, a post-doctoral scholar, and an advanced graduate student-- career-related questions.  


While it is difficult to quantify the impact that gatherings like these have on the careers and research programs of those involved, it is also hard to understate the need for venues through which researchers of all levels can connect and share ideas-- not only concerning their individual research programs, but also how they can include young talent or become a participant in the larger conversation. These conferences have been very worthwhile as clearinghouses for new ideas in topology, geometry, and dynamics; but with regard to this second goal of bringing together mathematicians at every stage of their academic careers, they have succeeded far beyond the organizers' expectations.
